content: Trade-based money laundering (TBML) involves exploiting the international trade system to transfer value and hide the origins of illicit wealth. The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) defines TBML as disguising crime proceeds through trade transactions. This typically includes misrepresenting prices, quantities, or quality of imports/exports, often used by terrorist groups to finance activities and disguise money movements. Trade-based money laundering (TBML) involves disguising crime proceeds through trade transactions by misrepresenting prices, quantities, or quality of imports/exports. TBML schemes, also known as TBML/FT when used by terrorist groups, aim to legitimize illicit funds and hide their origins. Financial institutions can be unwittingly involved in TBML and TBML/FT schemes when they settle, facilitate, or finance international trade transactions. The U.S. Department of the Treasury issued reports in June 2015 on money laundering risks, highlighting trade-based money laundering (TBML) as a significant challenge.
